channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nigerian Security Forces Detain 8 in Bombings, as World Economic Forum Nears
item.description: The United States Embassy warned Americans that terrorist groups may be planning “an unspecified attack” during the conference in the capital of Abuja, though President Goodluck Jonathan assured delegates that they would be safe.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sports: California Chrome Wins the Kentucky Derby
item.description: California Chrome, the speedy colt who established himself as the 5-2 morning-line favorite after winning four straight races by a combined 241/4 lengths, won the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA HOPPERT
item.media:description: California Chrome won the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby under blue skies and 70-degree weather at Churchill Downs.

item.title: Embrace of Atheism Put an Indonesian in Prison
item.description: The case of Alexander Aan, who was imprisoned after posting commentaries online, is part of a rise in persecution connected to freedom of religion in Indonesia in recent years.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Rony Zakaria for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexander Aan served more than 19 months in prison after publicly declaring himself an atheist.

item.title: Deadly Blasts Rock Port City in Kenya
item.description: At least three people were killed in two explosions in Kenya’s port city of Mombasa on Saturday, witnesses and the local news media said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Ukraine Presses Pro-Russia Militants After Fighting Spreads to a Port City
item.description: Even as European military observers held as suspected NATO spies were released Saturday, Russia cited bloody street violence in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebel checkpoint Saturday as Ukrainian troops pressed their assault on separatists in the east.

item.title: Call of Nature Becomes a Call to Arms in Hong Kong
item.description: As Hong Kong braces for demonstrations over voting rights, its relations with mainland China have been overshadowed by a more pedestrian issue: how to react when toddlers relieve themselves on the street.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A protest last week about Chinese tourists drew both sides of the Hong Kong/mainland divide.

item.title: Evacuation of Syrian Rebels From Western City Is Delayed
item.description: A cease-fire still held in Homs, where rebels had agreed to surrender territory in exchange for safe passage to other opposition-held areas.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Yemeni Army Officer Is Killed as Clashes With Militants Grow
item.description: Two soldiers were also killed in a bomb blast as the army waged a new offensive against Islamist militants in the south.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Islamic Jihad Gains New Traction in Gaza
item.description: Founded before Hamas and sharing a similar ideology, Islamic Jihad is growing, asserting itself as the main military expression of Palestinian nationalism.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: While Hamas is blamed for high unemployment, residents of Gaza have increasingly supported Islamic Jihad as it has expanded services. Above, a child being treated at a medical facility run by the group.

item.title: Bomb Kills 5 in Somali Capital
item.description: The Islamist extremist group Shabab claimed responsibility for the attack in Mogadishu, which appeared to target a top police officer.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Spite of the Law, Afghan ‘Honor Killings’ of Women Continue
item.description: The body of civil law enacted with Western assistance and the classic Islamic code of Shariah protect the rights of women not to be forced into marriage. Tribal codes do not.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zakia, 18, and Mohammad Ali, 21, in an undisclosed location in Afghanistan last month. They eloped against the wishes of Zakia’s family, and fear being killed.

item.title: Clear Rules Eyed on Church Sex Abuse
item.description: A commission will advise the pope on adopting policies developed from the existing “best practices” for the protection of minors, which can be implemented worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Marie Collins, center, and Cardinal Sean O’Malley, members of a Vatican commission addressing sex abuse in the church.

item.title: Behind the Masks in Ukraine, Many Faces of Rebellion
item.description: A deeper look at the rebels in Ukraine offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. They appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militiamen at their base in Slovyansk, Ukraine, last week. A deeper look at the rebels offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections. The rebels appear to be Ukrainians, but they have deep ties to and affinity for Russia.

item.title: ‘No Hope’ for Those Buried by Mudslide, Afghanistan Official Says
item.description: President Hamid Karzai declared Sunday a national day of mourning and ordered all flags flown at half-staff, after officials said they feared that more than 2,000 people were dead.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: 20 Are Held and Curfew Is Imposed After Attacks on Muslims in India
item.description: Police say the attacks were carried out by militants with an armed insurgent group that has been agitating for a separate state for decades.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Relatives of victims mourned at a burial ground at Narayanguri village, in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, on Saturday.

item.title: In Latest Government Shuffle, North Korean Leader Removes No. 2 Official From Top Posts
item.description: Seen less frequently accompanying the leader in his public activities, it remained unclear whether Vice Marshal Choe Ryong-hae was removed from other key positions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: For the past two years, Vice Marshal Choe Ryong-hae, left, has been head of the General Political Bureau of the North Korean People’s Army.

item.title: Death Stalks Muslims as Myanmar Cuts Off Aid
item.description: Myanmar’s Buddhist-led government has targeted the Rohingya people, depriving them of liberties even as it trumpets democratic reforms.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Quick History: Celebrating Sainthood and Witnessing Barbarity
item.description: The week’s two major events seemed to challenge the popular image of a linear march of human progress.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: A postcard shows portraits of John Paul II, right, and John XXIII, who were recognized as saints last week.

item.title: World Briefing: Ethiopia: Student Protesters Killed in Clashes With Police
item.description: At least 11 students have been killed in violent clashes with Ethiopian police in a region that has long been the scene of a secessionist movement, the government said late Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Police Revise Number of Kidnapped Students
item.description: The number of kidnapped schoolgirls missing in Nigeria has been revised to 276, up by more than 30 from a previous estimate, the police said late Thursday, adding that the actual number abducted by Islamic extremists on April 14 was more than 300.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Publicist Sentenced for Assaults on Women
item.description: Max Clifford, the influential British publicist best known for managing the reputations of celebrities, was sentenced Friday to eight years in prison for a string of indecent assaults on four women.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
item.description: At a White House meeting meant to mend fences, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said it was too soon to return to “business as usual” with the United States following disclosures that the N.S.A had eavesdropped on her phone calls.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany after a news conference in the Rose Garden on Friday.

item.title: Juan Formell, 71, Cuban Dance-Band Leader, Dies
item.description: Mr. Formell, the founder of Los Van Van, created an infectious, popular hybrid of Afro-Cuban music that influenced salsa performers like Ruben Blades.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:description: Juan Formell accepting a lifetime achievement award in 2013.

item.title: Plying Social Media, Chinese Workers Grow Bolder in Exerting Clout
item.description: A shrinking labor pool in China has shifted more bargaining power to workers, and a mass walkout illustrated their willingness to use it.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Signs supporting shoe factory workers were left outside a Nike shop in Hong Kong. The signs say “Blood and sweat factory.”

item.title: Accident Leads to Scrutiny of Oil Sand Production
item.description: A relatively minor leak last year has led regulators in Alberta to re-examine production that uses steam under pressure to separate oil from subterranean sands.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: Workers from Canadian Natural Resources, an oil company, cleaning up the marshy Primrose site in Alberta, Canada, in August.
